docs.lead_paragraph: Officials say the health care law has been stigmatized for many it could help, especially in states that are medically underserved but hostile to President Obama.

headline.main: In Poorest States, Political Stigma Is Depressing Participation in Health Law
headline.print_headline: In Poorest States, Political Stigma Is Depressing Participation in Health Law

docs.abstract: Health professionals and other officials say that political stigma, coming from partisan divisions and attack ads, has depressed enrollment in government health care program in poor states where many could benefit from it; problem is particularly keen in conservative states like West Virginia that have poorest, most medically underserved populations but where Pres Obama and his signature initiative are hugely unpopular.
docs.snippet: Officials say the health care law has been stigmatized for many it could help, especially in states that are medically underserved but hostile to President Obama.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Cost is the great taboo in U.S. health care. And we pay dearly.

headline.main: For Drugs That Save Lives, a Steep Cost
headline.print_headline: For Drugs That Save Lives, a Steep Cost

docs.abstract: News analysis; manufacturer of Evzio, pocket-size device that injects drug called naxolone to rescue people from overdoses of opiates, has declined to answer how much device will cost; device, which some expect could well be priced close to $500, offers example of way that price has become taboo subject in American health care system, trend that experts say is costing the country dearly.
docs.snippet: Cost is the great taboo in U.S. health care. And we pay dearly.

docs.lead_paragraph: The vast majority of Division I universities are public but the National Labor Relations Board has no power over them, only over private-sector employers like Northwestern.

headline.main: Union Effort at Northwestern May Not Mean Much for Public Colleges
headline.print_headline: Union Effort at Northwestern May Not Mean Much for Public Colleges

docs.abstract: Ruling by National Labor Relations Board that Northwestern’s scholarship football players could unionize leaves unanswered the question of what it means for nation's public universities' scholarship athletes; NLRB has no power over public universities, only over private-sector employers like Northwestern, meaning whether football or basketball players at a public university can unionize is up to its state government.
docs.snippet: The vast majority of Division I universities are public but the National Labor Relations Board has no power over them, only over private-sector employers like Northwestern.

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress gets back to work Monday after a two-week vacation, and it's looking like lawmakers will do what they do best: the bare minimum.

headline.main: Congress Returns to Work to Do the Bare Minimum
headline.print_headline: Congress Returns to Work to Do the Bare Minimum

docs.snippet: Congress gets back to work Monday after a two-week vacation, and it's looking like lawmakers will do what they do best: the bare minimum.

docs.lead_paragraph: The state will need to make sure that an infusion of federal funds generates real reform.
docs.abstract: Editorial applauds New York State plan to use $8 billion of federal funds over next five years to reform its Medicaid program for the poor; notes funds will go to improving delivery of health care for state's poorest residents while saving billions in unnecessary emergency room and medical costs; expresses hope that waiver money will drive real reform.
docs.snippet: The state will need to make sure that an infusion of federal funds generates real reform.

docs.lead_paragraph: An out-of-network requirement would make it difficult for health exchange plans with roots in the Medicaid system to compete, according to state officials.

headline.main: New York Will Keep Affordable Care Act Health Plans Restricted
headline.print_headline: New York Will Keep Health Plans Restricted

docs.abstract: New York State health officials say that they will not require out-of-network coverage on Affordable Care Act health plans next year, a decision likely to disappoint customers who have complained that they can no longer use their favorite doctors and hospitals; restricting consumers to a fixed network of doctors and hospitals, called in-network coverage, helps keep costs down.
docs.snippet: An out-of-network requirement would make it difficult for health exchange plans with roots in the Medicaid system to compete, according to state officials.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The Savannah Harbor Expansion Project has gone nowhere, even though Democrats and Republicans, Congress and the White House, agree it is essential and overdue.

headline.main: A Consensus in Washington, but No Action
headline.print_headline: A Consensus in Washington, but No Action

docs.abstract: Savannah Harbor Expansion Project, $652 million effort to expand the Georgia port, remains stalled despite strong support from both parties and Pres Obama; project has become latest emblem of toxic environment in Washington that has made inertia a powerful force, even where there is consensus.
docs.snippet: The Savannah Harbor Expansion Project has gone nowhere, even though Democrats and Republicans, Congress and the White House, agree it is essential and overdue.

docs.lead_paragraph: Black women face infertility more often than white women but are less likely to seek medical help, and their struggles are compounded by cultural issues.

headline.main: Infertility, Endured Through a Prism of Race
headline.print_headline: Infertility, Endured Through a Prism of Race

docs.abstract: Study conducted by National Center for Health Statistics from 2006 to 2010 finds that black women face infertility more often than white women but are less likely to seek medical help; experts say part of disparity in who seeks treatment has to do with paying for procedures that can cost tens of thousands of dollars.
docs.snippet: Black women face infertility more often than white women but are less likely to seek medical help, and their struggles are compounded by cultural issues.

docs.lead_paragraph: A couple can lose crucial pensions and benefits that they had before they tied the knot.

headline.main: Welcoming Love at an Older Age, but Not Necessarily Marriage
headline.print_headline: Welcoming Love at an Older Age, but Not Necessarily Marriage

docs.abstract: Older Americans are welcoming love in retirement, but not necessarily marriage; studies show they tend to want to avoid legal problems for heirs and provisions in tax code that force married couples to pay more than single people; United States Census Bureau statistics show growth of unmarried couples is fastest among older segment of population.
docs.snippet: A couple can lose crucial pensions and benefits that they had before they tied the knot.

docs.lead_paragraph: The European Commission said in a report on Friday that Greece had made enough progress to warrant disbursing 6.3 billion euros that had been held back.

headline.main: Despite Missing Economic Goals, Greece Manages to Meet a Bailout Target

docs.snippet: The European Commission said in a report on Friday that Greece had made enough progress to warrant disbursing 6.3 billion euros that had been held back.
